title: Clive Allen on the day Arsenal boss Arsene Wenger called Tottenham 'cheats'
text:

Clive Allen has relived the day Arsene Wenger called him and his Tottenham team 'cheats' - and said his behaviour left him wanting to 'punch' the legendary Arsenal boss.

Allen lifted the lid on a feud with Wenger that has simmered since 2006 - saying "I wouldn’t give him the time of day as long as I live".

The row dates back to a 1-1 draw between Tottenham and Wenger's Arsenal at Highbury in 2006.

Allen, who was a coach at Tottenham at the time, says Wenger took issue with Robbie Keane's goal for Spurs, as the visitors hadn't kicked the ball out of play following an accidental clash between Gunners players Emmanuel Eboue and Gilberto Silva.

Former Tottenham striker Allen says he was having a glass of wine with some of Arsenal's coaching staff after the game when Wenger burst in and accused Spurs of being 'cheats'.

(Image: Getty)

“I am not drinking with you - you are cheats," Wenger said according to an excerpt from Allen's autobiography 'Up Front', which was published by the Evening Standard .

He says when he challenged Wenger about his remarks, the Frenchman replied: "You are all cheats."

Allen says from that moment on he just wanted to shake Wenger's hand having got the better of his rival - but claims when the opportunity arrived, the Arsenal boss wouldn't reciprocate.

Tottenham beat Arsenal 5-1 in the 2008 League Cup semi-final, then in the Premier League in November 2010, but Wenger walked off each time, Allen says.

(Image: AFP/Getty Images)

A third opportunity came when Spurs beat the Gunners 2-1 at White Hart Lane in October 2011, and Wenger didn't shake his hand this time, Allen said he was "ready to punch him".

"Just as I went to swing for him, reserve goalkeeper Carlo Cudicini saved the day," Allen says. "He threw his arm over my shoulder. 'Clive, what was the score?' he said, smiling. He dragged me away and into our dressing room."

Allen goes on to say: "I wouldn’t give him the time of day as long as I live. It is not about football, it is the way he behaved."
description: Former Spurs coach says he was 'ready to punch' legendary Gunners boss after long-running feud
